dublinCore.dc:title: 114 HR 3990 IH: Start-up America’s Students Act
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mr. Swalwell of California (for himself, Mr. Gallego, Mr. Peters, Mr. Jeffries, Mr. Kilmer, and Mr. Murphy of Florida) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Small Business

form.official-title: To amend the Small Business Act to provide grants for university business incubators.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Start-up America’s Students Act .
The Small Business Act (15 U.S.C. 631 et seq.) is amended—

paragraph.text: by redesignating section 47 as section 48; and
by inserting after section 46 the following:

subsection.text: The Administrator, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, shall award grants, on a competitive basis, to eligible institutions for the purpose of establishing, maintaining, expanding, and improving business incubators operated by or affiliated with such eligible institutions.

An eligible institution desiring a grant under this section shall prepare and submit to the Administrator an application, at such time, in such manner, and containing such information as the Administrator, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, may require.

paragraph.text: The term business incubator means a facility that is primarily used to provide space where start-up businesses—

subparagraph.text: share space, support staff or services, physical resources, or overhead expenses; and
receive technical assistance, financial advice, or business planning services.

paragraph.text: The term eligible institution means an institution of higher education (as defined in section 102 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1002)) with a program participation agreement under section 487 of such Act (20 U.S.C. 1094).
The term start-up business means a small business concern that—

subparagraph.text: has been in operation for less than four years.
